title: My wife filed for divorce and put a separation date that is incorrect. Can I have the divorce stopped because of this?
question: My wife filed for divorce on November 3, 2009. She put that we had separated on October 1, 2009. We were still living together, going on dates, and sleeping in the same bed until November 3, when she said she wanted a divorce and went to a friendâ€™s house. She was gone for a few days and then she came back.
question_tags: Divorce,Contested divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Alimony,Filing for divorce,Divorce petitions and complaints,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and alimony,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Family law
answers:
Date of separation is an extremely important issue. If you disagree with it, you should put in the date that you believe is correct.

Date of separation has nothing to do with the date you moved out or the date you stopped marital counseling. Date of separation is when one party tells the other that s/he wants out of the marriage. This is usually verbal and, therefore, very hard to prove. So the court will look at other facts. Move out date is one of them (but not determinative, especially in this economy when most people can't afford a mortgage AND rent). Other factors include your conduct, and how you hold yourself out to the public. Basically, would an average person be able to tell that you are separated?

This gets complicated. I mediated a divorce case where the parties, both with attorneys, had already had a 3-day trial on the issue of date of separation only. It gets very expensive, as you can probably guess. But that's because it is so important - it's a cut-off for spousal support (if your marriage was less than 10 years), for community assets, and for community debts.

You should definitely consult an attorney who can assess your situation directly and best advise you. There are also a number of consensual dispute options that can help get the two of you through the process faster and for less than a contested divorce.

Good luck to you both.

Verify and assert the date of the separation and when you moved out in your papers that seek your relief. The judge will decide what the final outcome will be.

Check with a lawyer in your locale to discuss more of the details.

Good luck to you.

God bless.

I agree with all my colleagues; date of separation can be important because after separation, your debts are your own debts and your income is your own income. Sometimes the date of separation can be unclear.

But, let me add that to avoid similar questions about date of divorce, just go ahead and FILE for divorce and serve your papers. California's legal definition of separation is when at least one party treats the marriage as over. Moving out may or may not meet this definition. But filing for divorce and serving the papers makes a very clear statement that you are treating the marriage as over, and it establishes that you have separated.

My colleague is correct. You can object to the date of separation she chose and put in the date you believe is correct.

All that this date change will do is impact the amount of separate and community property available by a few dollars for the month or so discrepancy.
You cannot "stop" the divorce (or have the matter dismissed) for this reason. You can, however, allege a different date of separation in any Response you file.
